block.p: Elizabeth Roxas, a dancer, and Robert Z. Dobrish, a matrimonial lawyer, were married on Tuesday. Judge Jeffrey H. Gallet of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the National Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan. Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Roxas-Dobrish is a director of and a principal dancer with RhythMEK, a dance company in Manhattan. The bride, a former principal dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is also an adjunct professor of movement at the Hartt School at the University of Hartford. She is the daughter of Virginia Diaz Roxas of Spring Valley, N.Y., and the late Valeriano M. Roxas, who was a district attorney in Manila.

Elizabeth Roxas, a dancer, and Robert Z. Dobrish, a matrimonial lawyer, were married on Tuesday. Judge Jeffrey H. Gallet of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York officiated at the National Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan. Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann of State Supreme Court in Manhattan took part in the ceremony.

Mrs. Roxas-Dobrish is a director of and a principal dancer with RhythMEK, a dance company in Manhattan. The bride, a former principal dancer with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is also an adjunct professor of movement at the Hartt School at the University of Hartford. She is the daughter of Virginia Diaz Roxas of Spring Valley, N.Y., and the late Valeriano M. Roxas, who was a district attorney in Manila.

Mr. Dobrish is a partner in Hoffinger Friedland Dobrish & Stern, a Manhattan law firm. He graduated from Columbia University and the New York University School of Law. He is the son of the late Ehtel and Joseph Dobrish. The bridegroom's father owned the Abbey Shade and Manufacturing Company in Manhattan.
The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's.
